Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: Mathematical Modeling with Cultural and Community Contexts

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal was submitted in response to EHR Core Research (ECR) program announcement NSF 15-509. The ECR program of fundamental research in STEM education provides funding in critical research areas that are essential, broad and enduring. EHR seeks proposals that will help synthesize, build and/or expand research foundations in the following focal areas: STEM learning, STEM learning environments, STEM workforce development, and broadening participation in STEM. The ECR program is distinguished by its emphasis on the accumulation of robust evidence to inform efforts to (a) understand, (b) build theory to explain, and (c) suggest interventions (and innovations) to address persistent challenges in STEM interest, education, learning, and participation.

A team of investigators from the University of Arizona will conduct research on the teaching and learning of mathematical modeling in diverse elementary classrooms in Arizona and Washington. Mathematical modeling skills are foundational as they connect core mathematical ideas to real world experiences through analysis, representation, interpretation, and revision. Mathematical modeling also supports enduring understandings and practices in mathematics, such as problem solving and generalization. While mathematical modeling has a strong tradition in secondary education, the increased content of college and career readiness standards requires an introduction to modeling in elementary school. To address this need, the researchers will: (a) advance foundational knowledge on teaching and learning mathematical modeling in grades 3 through 5; (b) refine innovative professional development programs to increase teacher understanding and practice of mathematical modeling that draws on student experiences and relevant cultural and community contexts; and (c) develop a set of valid and reliable measures to evaluate teacher and student learning outcomes related to mathematical modeling. The project is funded by the EHR Core Research program, which supports fundamental research that advances the research literature on STEM learning, and has implications for education in both formal and informal settings.

The project will be conducted as a mixed methods, multi-tiered design experiment. Across the three project years, researchers will iteratively develop and refine a professional development model with cohorts of teachers in Arizona and Washington who work in high poverty schools with culturally and linguistically diverse populations. The researchers will measure the potential for impact of the model on mathematics instruction and student learning. The proposed work to design mathematical modeling tasks is based on tenets of progressive formalization Realistic Mathematics Education (RME), which suggest that contexts matter for supporting student learning of mathematical modeling. The model integrates research on teaching and learning of mathematical modeling, and research on the role of culturally and community based funds of knowledge in teaching and learning mathematics. As students work on modeling tasks, they will produce artifacts that include evidence of reasoning and thinking. They will also be assessed by means of a Common Core aligned State-level Standardized Mathematics Assessment measure. Teachers will adapt mathematical modeling tasks, design lessons around those tasks, and iteratively refine a set of reusable tools for assessing students modeling activity. To measure impact on student learning, the researchers will use a two-group design to compare student learning in classrooms of training condition teachers with student learning in comparable, non-training condition classrooms. Since few teachers currently use mathematical modeling instruction in grades 3-5, a teacher comparison group to measure impact on teacher learning will not be employed. Rather, the researchers will use participating teachers as their own controls to examine changes over time in their understanding and practice.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project has outcomes in several areas:

1. TEACHER LEARNING AND PRACTICE: We have identified multiple instructional routines that serve as entry points for teachers who are learning to teach mathematical modeling and for students who engage in the modeling process. These instructional routines (e.g., mathematizing the world routines, and assumption building routines) have been implemented and refined, in an iterative manner across our two research sites, and across our target grade level band. Analyses of the enactment of these routines have supported their effectiveness in supporting teachers and students in engaging in the first phase of the modeling process . 

2. STUDENT LEARNING OF MATHEMATICAL MODELING: We have advanced knowledge related to how students leverage their experiences and funds of knowledge to support their engagement in each phase of the mathematical modeling process. This is the result of multiple cross-site analysis of teachers? enactment of mathematical modeling tasks that connect to relevant situations in students? lives.

3. M2C3 SUMMER INSTITUTE: Based on participant feedback and preliminary analyses of teachers? planning and enactment of modeling lessons during the 2017-2018 academic year, we made adjustments with each iteration of the summer institutes. During 2017-2018 we found that teachers frequently requested additional support for designing modeling lessons for their own classrooms. In response, in the 2018 institute, we introduced a new tool that categorized modeling tasks (descriptive, predictive, optimizing, and rating and ranking), and refined the PD activities to showcase specific math content connections (number & operations, and fractions), and cultural (family) and community connections, and student work and video exemplars. We also introduced an additional mathematizing routine based on our analysis of 2017-2018  lesson enactments. We also revised key project tools to support teacher knowledge of mathematical modeling. During summer 2018, we found that participating teachers were able to differentiate math modeling tasks from traditional word problems, adapt curricula tasks to be math modeling friendly, and design modeling tasks that connect to local community contexts. Additionally, in summer 2018 we found that the integration of current and new teacher participants supported teachers? understandings about mathematical modeling, and about their students? capacity to engage in rigorous, relevant modeling tasks. 

4. ACADEMIC YEAR STUDY GROUPS: Our ongoing analyses of monthly professional development sessions at each site demonstrate that teachers used tools and resources introduced in the summer institutes as they implemented tasks with students. Teachers also provided extensive feedback about the lesson planning process in particular, and in response we streamlined planning tools for task design and enactment, and introduced refined curriculum adaptation tools to help teachers modify problems to be more community-based and modeling friendly. Also, our analysis of common task enactments from  2017-2018 revealed particular components of modeling that posed challenges for teachers and students and in response we worked with teachers to design additional supports for these portions of the modeling process.

5. TASK DEVELOPMENT and COMMON TASK ENACTMENTS: (a) We successfully developed a new set of two common mathematical modeling tasks each year, as a way to measure teachers' learning and enactment of MM, as well as to understand how students engage and learn from MM.

(b) We also found that a subset of teachers at each site developed math modeling tasks that reflected relevant questions and contexts in their schools and communities. We found that teachers leveraged various M2C3 tools to support this task development work, including a) a M2C3 tool that outlined different types of modeling tasks, with illustrative examples, and b) project developed modeling tasks that teachers used as templates to create tasks relevant to their schools and communities

(c) Many project teachers across sites worked on adapting word problems from required mathematics curricula to be more modeling friendly and locally relevant to students? experiences and schools.

6. DIGITAL LIBRARY: The website is publicly available (https://sites.google.com/qc.cuny.edu/m2c3/home).  The website has been shared with researchers and mathematics teacher educators across the country via national conference presentations, and with local school district partners via our professional development initiatives.  

7. VALID AND RELIABLE MEASURES FOR EVALUATING TEACHER LEARNING OUTCOMES: M2C3-SCAN: After examining the scores on the M2C3-Scan from Y1, we noted that the scores were largely parallel to those of any problem solving lesson and that we were not capturing the particularities of math modeling lessons. For this reason, we revised the M2C3-Scan protocol substantially for use in Y2. An initial examination of Y2 scores indicates that the revisions are helping us capture variations among teachers related to some of the nuances that make math modeling lessons different from other problem solving lessons.

8. VALID AND RELIABLE MEASURES FOR EVALUATING STUDENT LEARNING: Rubrics for coding open-ended questions are finalized. Analysis is ongoing.
